SEARCH
Package farm.sales.transaction

Class CategorisedTransaction

Object
Transaction
CategorisedTransaction
Direct Known Subclasses:
SpecialSaleTransaction
public class CategorisedTransaction extends Transaction
A transaction type that allows products to be categorised by their types, not solely as isolated individual products. The resulting receipt therefore displays purchased types with an associated quantity purchased and subtotal, rather than a single line for each product.
Component of Stage 1.

  • Constructor Details

    • CategorisedTransaction

      public CategorisedTransaction(Customer customer)
      Construct a new categorised transaction for an associated customer. Transactions should always be active at the time of creation, i.e. a transaction cannot already be set to finalised upon instantiation.
      Parameters:
      customer - the customer who is starting the transaction (beginning to shop).

  • Method Details

    • getPurchasedTypes

      public Set<Barcode> getPurchasedTypes()
      Retrieves all unique product types of the purchases associated with the transaction.
      Returns:
      a set of all product types in the transaction.

    • getPurchasesByType

      public Map<Barcode,List<Product>> getPurchasesByType()
      Retrieves all products associated with the transaction, grouped by their type.
      If the transaction has been finalised, this is all products that were 'locked in' as final purchases at that time. If the transaction is instead still active, it is all products currently in the associated customer's cart.
      Returns:
      the products in the transaction, grouped by their type.

    • getPurchaseQuantity

      public int getPurchaseQuantity(Barcode type)
      Retrieves the number of products of a particular type associated with the transaction.
      Parameters:
      type - the product type.
      Returns:
      the number of products of the specified type associated with the transaction.

    • getPurchaseSubtotal

      public int getPurchaseSubtotal(Barcode type)
      Determines the total price for the provided product type within this transaction.
      Parameters:
      type - the product type.
      Returns:
      the total price for all instances of that product type within the transaction, or 0 if no items of that type are associated with the transaction.

    • getReceipt

      public String getReceipt()
      Converts the transaction into a formatted receipt for display, using the ReceiptPrinter.

      If the transaction has not been finalised, an accurate receipt cannot be printed; use ReceiptPrinter.createActiveReceipt() to create an empty receipt reporting this.

      Otherwise, use the ReceiptPrinter.createReceipt(List, List, String, String). The displayed transaction must match the following requirements:

      • The headings must be "Item", "Qty", "Price (ea.)", and "Subtotal", in that order.
      • Each entry must be a list containing the identifier of a product type, the number of products of that type purchased, the price per item for that type, and the subtotal for that type.
      • The entries in the list should appear in the order matching that of Barcode.values(). Product types for which no items were purchased should not be included.
      • All prices shown on the receipt – that is, both prices per product and the overall total - must be styled in standard price format rather than as cents, e.g. 157c becomes $1.57.
       
 Customer jack = new Customer("Jack", 01234567, "1st Street");

 jack.getCart().addProduct(new Egg());
 jack.getCart().addProduct(new Milk());
 jack.getCart().addProduct(new Jam());
 jack.getCart().addProduct(new Egg());
 jack.getCart().addProduct(new Milk());
 jack.getCart().addProduct(new Egg());

 Transaction transaction = new CategorisedTransaction(jack);
 transaction.finalise();

 System.out.println(transaction.getReceipt());

      Overrides:
      getReceipt in class Transaction
      Returns:
      the styled receipt representation of this transaction
      Hint:
      remember that sets and maps in Java are not ordered. If you are using either of these to keep track of purchased product types (which is a perfectly good idea!), you must ensure you find a way to control the order in which you retrieve things from them.
